parse: Verb - Present Participle Active - Nominative Masculine Plural
str2: To have, hold, possess. Including an alternate form scheo skheh'-o; a primary verb; to hold.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive 2nd Person Plural
str2: You. The person pronoun of the second person singular; thou.
Properly, beautiful, but chiefly good, i.e. Valuable or virtuous.
In, on, among. A primary preposition denoting position, and instrumentality, i.e. A relation of rest; 'in, ' at, on, by, etc.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Probably from etho; a race, i.e. A tribe; specially, a foreign one.
In order that, so that. Probably from the same as the former part of heautou; in order that.

parse: Personal / Relative Pronoun - Dative Neuter Singular
str2: Who, which, what, that.

parse: Verb - Present Indicative Active - 3rd Person Plural
str2: To speak evil of, rail at, slander. From katalalos; to be a traducer, i.e. To slander.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive 2nd Person Plural
str2: You. The person pronoun of the second person singular; thou.
Probably adverb of comparative from hos; which how, i.e. In that manner.
Doing evil; subst: an evil-doer. From kakos and poieo; a bad-doer;, a criminal.

parse: Verb - Present Participle Active - Nominative Masculine Plural
str2: To be an eyewitness of, behold, look upon. From epi and a derivative of optanomai; to inspect, i.e. Watch.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Properly, beautiful, but chiefly good, i.e. Valuable or virtuous.
From a primary ergo; toil; by implication, an act.

parse: Verb - Aorist Subjunctive Active - 3rd Person Plural
str2: To glorify, honor, bestow glory on. From doxa; to render glorious.
A deity, especially the supreme Divinity; figuratively, a magistrate; by Hebraism, very.
In, on, among. A primary preposition denoting position, and instrumentality, i.e. A relation of rest; 'in, ' at, on, by, etc.
A day, the period from sunrise to sunset.
From episkeptomai; inspection; by implication, superintendence; specially, the Christian 'episcopate'.
